Post Template
Only my post’s are long enough to need scroll down
src/components/ScrollDawon.jsx
jsx
1<ScrollDown
2 direction='down' to={15}
3 showAbove={1500}
4 css='position: fixed; right: 1em; top: 4.5em;'
5 />
Scroll down is visible at the top of the page and is fixed. I think its cool and somewhat original. Not static like the Netlify build page has scroll to bottom of the build log or back to top which is pretty Cool.

item.title: React GitHub Comments Utterances
item.description: React GitHub Comments Utterances uses withUtterances React npm module. Built with React Hooks and Love
item.dc:creator: Donald Boulton
item.content:encoded:
<svg fill="#DC26className=assName="inline-block mr-4 pr-4 h-6 w-6 bottom-1 right-2 text-red-600" fillRule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd">React withUtterances Repo
<svg filclassName=2626" className="inline-block mr-4 pr-4 h-6 w-6 bottom-1 right-2 text-red-600" fillRule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd">Why use withUtterances as utterances
👽 Taken From: bhnywl.com
Lets say all your users are developers and already have a GitHub account so they don’t need to sign up for yet another 3rd party service like Disqus (which will also track their every move through the web 😈) Unlike Staticman that I am using for my Reviews, GitHub Issues are truly dynamic so new comments will show without having to wait for your site to rebuild and deploy You get access to all the features of GitHub Issues out of the box (notifications, moderation, reactions, etc.) Developers care about the appearance of their GitHub accounts, which is likely to result in better (or at least civil) discussion. It’s free and open source!
If your users are more privacy-minded then Disqus may not be the right fit. Software developers, for example, are extremely privacy conscious. As my blog is aimed at other software developers I use Utterances as a comment system. However, remember that your readers will need a GitHub account to leave a comment using Utterances so if your target audience do not work (or play!) within the tech industry this will not be the comment system for you.
className=ill="#DC2626" className="inline-block mr-4 pr-4 h-6 w-6 bottom-1 right-2 text-red-600" fillRule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd">React withUtterances
Utterances Utterances
❤️
WithUtterances is a React Higher-Order-Component for Super LightWeight Comments Widget named Utterances.
No need Duplicated DOM Bindings for each react component
Just Wrap It
import withUtterances from 'with-utterances'
Wrap your react component
Pass your repo as a String
Done!
<a href="#InstallaticlassName=ia-label="Installation permalink" className="a.anchor right-2 botclassName=mr-4 pr-4 before">Installation
<button style="border:none;box-shadow:none;text-decoration:none;position:absolute;top:8px;right:0;margin-right:10px;margin-bottom:10px" css="[object Object]" aria-labelclassName= to clipboard" title="Copy to clipboard"><path d="M20 6L9 17L4 12" stroke="#5184f9" strokeWidth="2" strokeLinecap="round" strokeLinejoin="round" opacity="0" pathLength="1" stroke-dashoffset="0pxclassName=ke-dasharray="0px 1px">
sh
<span className="line-number-className=>1npclassName=th-utterances
2yarn add with-utterances
Usage
add wiclassName=rances to the file which has component that you want to show utterances comment widget.

<span className="line-number-className=>21<span className="token plain" style="display:inline-blockclassName=pan>
22<span classclassName=token plain"><span className="token keyword" style="color:rgclassName= 147, 249);font-style:italicclassName=rt <span className="token keyword" style=className=:rgb(189, 147, 249);font-style:italic">default<span classNamclassName=en plain"> withUtterances<span classclassName=token punctuation" style="color:rgb(248, 248, 242)">(PostPage, 'YOUR_REPO'<span className="token punctuation" styleclassName=r:rgb(248, 248, 242)">, 'github-light', 'og:title')
It uses your pathname as issue-term.
Supported Themes
By default Utterances comes with two choices for themes:
github-light - The normal GitHub style
github-dark - A dark mode in the style of GitHub
More themes can be added with additional stylesheets.
Supported IsclassName=rms
pathname - Issue title which contains the path of the current page.
url - Issue title which contains the URL of the current page.
title - Issue title which contains the tab title of the current page.
og:title - Issue title which contains the Open Graph title meta.
<serach term> - Issue title which contains the given String.
PS. preload and prefetch Applied
It will make your Utterances Widget to load slightly faster. <3
PS. DEMO SITE
Demo Using withUtterance
My withUtterances react Component
Using GitHub pages dark theme. From the SEO component, ‘og:title’, to set the comment to a specific page. And this component with the specific meta-tags can be used, ‘anywhere’, not just posts!

Issues total counclassName=on
You could add a issues total count button which links to your repo page issues.
Using react-github-btn
Then you can go to Button github.io to configure your buttons.
My new trick to get around window or .document module errors, which this ‘react-github-btn’ is an offending npm module is to…
First call the offending Module

If you are a developer and use React this is a cool and logical way to have comments.
In my next post I will tie this component to Google Analytics as GitHub Issues.

Not only does this waste computational ressources since there’s nclassName= to rerender the map if the className=d props do not pertain to it, it also ruins the user experience since the map will jclassName=ck to its initial zoom levelclassName=enter on every rerender. To prevent this, you can easily create a memoized mapclassName=the useCallback hooclassName=v> 1import React,} frclassName=an> 'react' 2className=>'./components/Maps&className=/span> 3 4const MemoMclassName=pan>= useCclassName=k(/>className=n> []) 5 6export default () => ( 7
8

This is a memoized map

9 {MemoMap}className=>1011) In fact, you may want to maclassName=s part of the Map coclassName=t by default, i.e. diff diff 1- export default function Map({ options, onMount, className }) { 2+ function Map({ options, onMount, className }) { 3 ... 4} 5 6+ export default props => useCallback(, [])

item.title: React Hooks Masonry
item.description: Now that we have React Hooks, so many components can be rewritten in a more succinct, readable and maintainable manner.
item.dc:creator: Donald Boulton
item.content:encoded:
<svg fill="#DC26className=assName="inline-block mr-4 pr-4 h-6 w-6 bottom-1 right-2 text-red-600" fillRule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd">React Hooks Masonry
🔗 janosh.io React Hooks Masonry
🔥 Now that we have React Hooks, so many components can (and probably should 🔗 despite what Dan said at React Conf) be rewritten in a more succinct, readable and maintainable manner. A perfect candidate for this in my own code base was a Masonry component that used to rely on CSS grid with very narrow rows and managing the number of rows each child item spans based on its natural height to control their placement. With hooks, it was easy to significantly improve on this approach.
For those unfamiliar with “masonry” on the web, the goal is to create a layout like this.
The new implementation uses only 36 lines of codes and is about as plug-and-play as components get.<button style="border:none;box-shadow:none;text-decoration:none;position:absolute;top:8px;right:0;margin-right:10px;margin-bottom:10px" css="[object Object]" aria-label="Copy to clipboard" title="Copy to clipclassName=>

item.title: React Hooks Modal
item.description: React Hooks Modal
item.dc:creator: Donald Boulton
item.content:encoded:
<svg fill="#DC26className=assName="inline-block mr-4 pr-4 h-6 w-6 bottom-1 right-2 text-red-600" fillRule="evenodd" clip-rule="evenodd">React Hooks Modal
Taken from 🔗 janosh.io
🔥 Ready to start coding. But what to do first? One thing that seemed a good fit for hooks are modals. I’d implemented them once or twice before and in both cases came away with the feeling that a class component with all its boilerplate is overkill considering the tiny bit of state management required for modal functionality. As expected, using hooks I was able to boil it down quite considerably. This is what I ended up with.
What to do on a cold and wet January weekend? Why not check out the new React alpha (16.8).
The one with Hooks as it’s come to be called.
All it took was a little skimming through 🔗 the docs, followed by updating react and react-dom.<button style="border:none;box-shadow:none;text-decoration:none;position:absolute;top:8px;right:0;margin-right:10px;margin-bottom:10px" css="[object Object]" aria-label="Copy to clipboard" title="Copy to clipclassName=>
<div className="gatsby-highlight" style="bg:highlight;background:highlight;padding:4px 6px;color:white;border-radius:5px 0px 0px className=h<div className="gatsby-highligclassName=ta-language="sh">

<div styleclassName=tion:relative">
src/components/modal.js

As you can see, the styles are longer than the component itself. That’s where I spent most of my time too. Figuring out how to use React hooks took mere minutes. Props to the React team (pun intended) for the excellent onboarding experience!
Anyways, regarding usage, notice that the modal component doesn’className=ally handle it’s own state. That’s done by the parent component. As an example here’s a 🔗 list of photos that when clicked enter a higher-resolution modal view.

Admittedly this component is bloated further by using Redux but evenclassName=ut it, it’s much harder to read and maintain. I’d call this use case a definite win for React Hooks!
Semantic HTML
One thing I should mention for future readers who want to use this Modal component: Once Chrome’s new 🔗<dialog> tag gets better browser support, it would improve semantics to use it for the modal container, i.e.

However, bear in mind tclassName=ing ::backdrop would make it more difficult to close the modal on clclassName=utside of it, i.e. on the backgrclassName=This is because React is unable to attachclassName=>onClick event handlers to className=-elements and it seems unlikely this will change down the roadclassName=rkaround would be to use the new useRef andclassName=>useEffect hook to create aclassName=t listener on the browser’sclassName=>window object that checks for the target of the click event. ThaclassName=d complicate things a littleclassName=gh, since the listener would have to trigger on all clicks and check that the modal doesnclassName=lude the target before closiclassName=mething like so:

The new styled components Next and Prev share most of their CSS with Close so it makes sense to reuse that:
src/styles/style.jsx
js
1import styled, { css } from 'styled-components'
2
3import { Close as Cross } from '@styled-icons/material/Close'
4import { NavigateNext } from '@styled-icons/material/NavigateNext'
5import { NavigateBefore } from '@styled-icons/material/NavigateBefore'
6
7const controlsCss = css`
8 position: absolute;
9 cursor: pointer;
10 z-index: 1;
11 color: ${props => props.white && `white`};
12 background: ${props => props.white && `rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)`};
13 border-radius: 50%;
14 padding: 0.1em;
15 transition: ${props => props.theme.shortTrans};
16 :hover {
17 transform: scale(1.07);
18 }
19`
20
21export const Close = styled(Cross).attrs({ size: `2em` })`
22 ${controlsCss};
23 top: 0.5em;
24 right: 0.4em;
25`
26
27export const Next = styled(NavigateNext).attrs({ size: `2em` })`
28 ${controlsCss};
29 top: 50%;
30 right: 0.4em;
31`
32
33export const Prev = styled(NavigateBefore).attrs({ size: `2em` })`
34 ${controlsCss};
35 top: 50%;
36 left: 0.4em;
37`
For the full and most up to date implementation of this component, check out 🔗 this site’s Github repo.

item.title: Netlify CMS
item.description: Netlify CMS backend for editing data and site pages
item.dc:creator: Donald Boulton

content:encoded.h2: Netlify CMS
content:encoded.div: 🔥 Static + content management = ❤️
🔗 CMS Site
content:encoded.h3: Netlify Cms App
content:encoded.div: Netlify CMS adding to Gatsby with netlify-cms-app, is the best way to do it in 2020 as Netlify Cms App Netlify CMS app always creates its own DOM element for mounting the application.
Best advice if you want to use Netlify CMS with Gatsby is to follow the Code in Gatsby Starter Netlify Cms.
Added presentation slides from Netlify Cms Presentations
Or check out how I did it in this website in my PubliusLogic Github Repo.
There is lots of documentation on Netlify CMS so I do not have to rewrite that here.
Get the speed, security, and scalability of a static site, while still providing a convenient editing interface for content.

An integrated part of your Git workflow Content is stored in your Git repository along side your code for easier versioning, multi-channel publishing, and the option to handle content updates directly in Git.
content:encoded.h3: An extensible CMS
content:encoded.div: Netlify CMS is built as a single-page React app. Create custom-styled previews, UI widgets, and editor plugins or add a backend to support different Git platform APIs. My Netlify CMS backend will build and add Pages, Posts, My layout components with Event data for GCal fullCalendar localized events, Notifications, Authors, Products, Site Updates and charts data using charts.js displaying build, sales and analytics charts data on individual pages and posts. All edited from a CMS Backend on a Static Website!
content:encoded.h2: Installation
content:encoded.div: yarn add gatsby-plugin-netlify-cms netlify-cms-app
content:encoded.h3: gatsby.config file add
CMS file in src
content:encoded.div: Add to folder under src/cms/cms.js
content:encoded.h3: The Configuration file
content:encoded.div: Change this config.yml file to your site needs.

item.title: 0BSD Licence
item.description: The BSD Zero Clause License, explained.
item.dc:creator: Rob Landley

content:encoded.h2: Introduction

blockquote.div: Photo by Tim Mossholder on Unsplash

content:encoded.div: The 0BSD (Zero-Clause BSD) licence was originated by Rob Landley in Toybox. It’s also known as “Free Public License 1.0.0” and is similar to the MIT No Attribution License.
It is an extremely permissive licence, as it does not require the user to include the copyright notice, license text, or disclaimer in either source or binary forms.
content:encoded.h2: Origin
content:encoded.div: Rob Landley posted this in the Toybox mailing list on 13 March 2013 to introduce the 0BSD licence which was subsequently adopted by the Toybox project.

blockquote.div: Nobody but me is likely to care, but I’d like to simplify the first paragraph from the current:

Permission to use, copy, modify, and/or distribute this software for any purpose with or without fee is hereby granted, provided that the above copyright notice and this permission notice appear in all copies.
To just say:
Permission to use, copy, modify, and/or distribute this software for any purpose with or without fee is hereby granted.

Reasoning: it was never my intent to require anybody to copy license text into another project if they cut and pasted something out of toybox. The “permission for any purpose” is as close to public domain as you can get in our current screwed up legal system without making people uncomfortable the other way. (Besides, my initial reading of that was “all copies of the source code” but that’s not what it says, and somebody pointed out that Android has “show license text” options because paranoid lawyers think that sort of thing applies to the BINARY version, which is nuts.)

I’m not changing it this release, but in case anybody was going to object I thought I’d post it here for a bit first so I can remove your code if it really matters to you. This version is still outgoing-compatible with the old version (code that says the new thing can give code to a project that says the old thing, whether it could receive it depends on how paranoid your lawyers are).
Rob

content:encoded.h2: 0BSD Template

div.span: Permission to use, copy, modify, and/or distribute this software for any purpose with or without fee is hereby granted.

AND THE AUTHOR DISCLAIMS ALL WARRANTIES WITH REGARD TO THIS SOFTWARE INCLUDING ALL IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS. IN NO EVENT SHALL THE AUTHOR BE LIABLE FOR ANY SPECIAL, DIRECT, INDIRECT, OR CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES OR ANY DAMAGES WHATSOEVER RESULTING FROM LOSS OF USE, DATA OR PROFITS, WHETHER IN AN ACTION OF CONTRACT, NEGLIGENCE OR OTHER TORTIOUS ACTION, ARISING OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE USE OR PERFORMANCE OF THIS SOFTWARE.
